body_html:
@Giszy Yes, you may be right. But there're some major factors that I don't want to support this.

  1. The serialization part is broken. You can just try torch.save or torch.load, and you will get a error.
  2. CUDA is not supported. No compiler is usable to build that under Windows.
  3. Python 2 only supports the integral type long as the argument type in the Python function, which is not so friendly under Windows.
    The second reason is critical. It means that the users using it will be very limited. They may just build from source when needed.

body:
@Giszy Yes, you may be right. But there're some major factors that I don't want to support this.
1. The serialization part is broken. You can just try `torch.save` or `torch.load`, and you will get a error. 
2. CUDA is not supported. No compiler is usable to build that under Windows.
3. Python 2 only supports the integral type `long` as the argument type in the Python function, which is not so friendly under Windows.
The second reason is critical. It means that the users using it will be very limited. They may just build from source when needed.
